The Layer 2 buffer model between the TCP and the wireless transmission

Overview

1. The MMPP/G/1 queue — layer 2 buffer model
2. The arrival process — the Markovian TCP source model
3. The service process — the Markovian wireless transmission model, considering HARQ and ARQ process

Introduction

I.连续参数的Markov链

P{X(tn+1)=in+1|X(tk)=ik,0≤k≤n}=P{X(tn+1)=in+1|X(tn)=in}

II.齐次Markov链

P{X(s+t)=j|X(s)=i}=P{X(t)=j|X(0)=i}=pij(t)

The matrix P(t)={pij}(i,j∈S) 是概率转移矩阵，满足C-K方程

P(s+t)=P(s)+P(t)P(0)=Ilimt→0P(t)=I

由上面的C-K方程P(t)可表示为P(t)=I+∑n=1∞tnn!Qn
显然，P(t)完全由矩阵Q确定，并且有

P′(0)=limt→0P(t)−P(0)t=limt→0P(t)−It=Q

III.平稳分布及其矩阵计算

由定义知：π=πP(t), πQ=0, πeT=0. 具有m状态的连续Markov链，可计算出平稳分布为

π=e(Q+Θ)−1

where e=(1,1,…,1), and Θ is a m×m matrix.

IV.The 2-state MMPP/G/1 Queue

In 2-state MMPP/G/1 queue π is given by

π=(π1,π2)=1σ1+σ2(σ2,σ1)g=(g1,g2)=1G1+G2(G2,G1)

We write Q=[−σ1σ2σ1−σ2],Λ=[λ100λ2],G=[1−G1G2G11−G2], λ¯¯=πλ=λ1σ2+λ2σ1σ1+σ2

In simulation experiment, we set the MMPP parameters that used in “Steady-state analysis of the MMPP/G/1/K queue”
Λ=[1.072200.48976],Q=[−8.4733×10−45.0201×10−68.4733×10−4−5.0201×10−6],P=[0.994110.994110.005890.00589],π=(0.9941103,0.0058897),λ¯¯=1.06877,μ=2.181162

According to the LST (Laplac-Stieltjies Transform) L[f(x)], we know:

L[f(x)]={[s00s]−[−σ1−σ2σ1σ2]+[λ100λ2]}−1[λ100λ2]=1detA[s+σ2+λ2σ2σ1s+σ1λ1][λ100λ2]=1detA[(s+σ2+λ2)λ1λ1σ2λ2σ1(s+σ1+λ1)λ2]

where detA=(s+σ1+λ1)(s+σ2+λ2)−σ1σ2
不失一般性，我们假设 MMPP 从一到达时刻开始，在到达时刻嵌入的马尔可夫链的稳态分布是：

ψ=πΛπλ=1σ2λ1+σ1λ2[σ2λ1σ1λ2]

so, the LST of the arrival interval:

L=ψ{1detA[(s+σ2+λ2)λ1λ1σ2λ2σ1(s+σ1+λ1)λ2]}e=s(σ1λ22+σ2λ21)+(σ1λ2+σ2λ1)(σ1λ2+λ1λ2+σ2λ1)(σ1λ2+σ2λ1)[s2+(σ1+σ2+λ1+λ2)s+(σ1λ2+λ1λ2+σ2λ1)]=0.21s+0.220.42(s2+1.56s+0.53)

We derive the ILST (Inverse Laplace-Stieltjes Transform) of L[X]

l[x]=0.49e−0.5t+0.01e−1.06t

A.The number of arrivals over the interval

If Nt is the number of arrivals over the interval (0,t], then the mean of Nt is shown in

E(Nt)=πλt=λ1σ2+λ2σ1σ1+σ2t

Var(Nt)=E(N2t)−[E(Nt)]2=πλt+2t[(πλ)2−πΛ(Q+eπ)−1]+2πΛ(eQt−I)(Q+eπ)−2λ

In “A Markov Modulated Characterization of Packetized Voice and Data Traffic and Related Statistical Multiplexer Performance”, it defines the limiting index of dispersion

I(t)=Var[Nt]E[Nt]=1+A−AB(1−e−B)

where A=2(λ1−λ2)2σ1σ2(σ1+σ2)2(λ1σ2+λ2σ1), B=(σ1+σ2)t, A=9.449931582763375, B=0.00085235t

B.The vartual waiting time distribution

In 2-state MMPP/G/1 queue the LST of the vartual waiting time, can be derive as follow:
wv(s)=s(1−ρ)[(s−σ1−σ2)+(H(s)−1)(g1λ2+g2λ1)]s2+[(H(s)−1)(λ1+λ2)−(σ1+σ2)]s+(H(s)−1)[(H(s)−1)λ1λ2−σ1λ2−σ2λ1]

wv(s)=s(1−ρ)[(s−σ1−σ2)+(H(s)−1)(g1λ2+g2λ1)][s+λ1(H(s)−1)−σ1][s+λ2(H(s)−1)−σ2]−σ1σ2

where ρ is the traffic intensity, ρ=hλ¯¯≤1; and H(s) is the LST of H˜(x)

Wa(s)=shρ(1−H(s))⋅(wv(s)+ρ−1)=1λ¯¯⋅Wv(s)λ

wv=12(1−ρ)[2ρ+λ¯¯h(2)−2h((1−ρ)g+hπΛ)(Q+eπ)−1λ]

wa=1ρ(wv−12λ¯¯h(2))

The steady-state vector of G satisfies

G=∫∞0e(Q−Λ+ΛG)xdH˜(x)gG=g,ge=1

Using Newtow-Raphson method to get the numerical result

G=Λ−1(2μI+Λ−Q),g=(g1,g2)=1σ1λ1+σ2λ2(σ2λ2,σ1λ1)g=(0.00588774,0.99411226)

C.The aggregate probability of packet loss

Compute qi

We assume that losses only occur in the direction from the sender to the receiver (no loss of ACKs) and that any segment has a fixed probability p to get lost. More precisely, the random variable defined by the number of consecutive segments that are transmitted before loss has a geometric distribution with parameter 1−p
The probability qi that a loss is due to TO when Wc=i is given by:

qi=1if i≤2b+1

and

qi=[1−(1−p)2b+1][1+(1−p)2b+1−(1−p)i]1−(1−p)i if i≥2b+1

D.The mean throughput of the continous time finite capacity queue

We define the long-term steady-state TCP throughput Tp to be

Tp=limt→∞Tpt=limt→∞Ntt

Because Tp is the number of packets sent per unit of time regardless of loss, Tpt represents the throughput of the connection, distinguished with goodput.

  • The goodput of TCP connection is defined as

    Gp=limt→∞Gpt=limt→∞(1−qi−p)Ntt

    The goodput is computed as the mean number of segments successfully transmitted during a cycle over the mean duration of a cycle.

1. The MMPP/G/1 queue

1.1 The arrival process — Markov-Modulated Poisson Process(MMPP)

The MMPP is a doubly stochastic process and the arrival rate is λ∗[J(t)].

The arrival rate of MMPP depends on the state of the source. The state of the source J(t) is a m-states irreducible Markov process, and when the source is in state i, i.e. J(t)=i. the arrival rate is λi

The MMPP is parameterized by the m-state continuous Markov process with infinitesimal generator Q and the m Poisson arrival rate λ1,λ2,…,λm:

Q=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢−σ1σ21⋮σm1σ12−σ2⋮σm2⋯⋯⋱⋯σ1mσ2m⋮−σm⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥

σi=∑j=1, j≠imσij

Λ=diag(λ1,λ2,…,λm)

λ=(λ1,λ2,…,λm)T

In our analysis, we assume that \boldsymbol{Q} is homogeneous and steady-state vector of the Markov chain is π:

πQ=0,πe=1

where e=(1,1,…,1)T. And the
mean steady-state arrival rate generated by the mean steady-state arrival rate generated by the MMPP is λ¯¯=πλ
MMPP的初始状态（初始概率矢量），即ψ=P[J0=i] and ∑iψi=1. 根据所选的初始矢量的不同，有：
(a)一个从任意到达时刻开始、间隔稳定的MMPP，可以证明其初始矢量是：

ψ=πΛ/λ¯¯

(b)一个环境稳定的MMPP，初始概率矢量是 Q 的稳态矢量 π. 时间起点不是一个到达时刻，而是按确保环境马尔可夫过程是稳态的原则来选取。
依据上述模型，我们来分析 MMPP 的到达间隔时间分布。设 Xn 表示第 (n-1) 个包和第 n 个包之间的到达间隔时间，and Jn be the state of the Markov process at the kth arrival. So the sequence (Jn,Xn),n≥0 is a Markov renewal process, and state transition probability matrix is given by

F(x)=∫x0exp[(Q−Λ)τ]dτΛ=[e(Q−Λ)τ]∣∣x0(Q−Λ)−1Λ={e(Q−Λ)x−I}(Q−Λ)−1Λ

矩阵元素 Fij(x) 是条件概率：Fij=P{Jn=j,Xn≥x|Jn−1=i}
F(x) 对 x 进行微分，可以求得状态转移概率密度矩阵：

f(x)=ddxF(x)={e(Q−Λ)x(Q−Λ)}(Q−Λ)−1Λ=e(Q−Λ)xΛ

对上式进行拉普拉斯变换有：

L[f(x)]=∫∞0e(Q−Λ)xe−sxdxΛ=[−(sI−Q+Λ)−1e−(sI−Q+Λ)x]∣∣∞0Λ=(sI−Q+Λ)−1Λ

Let Nt be the number of arrivals in (0,t]
and Jt be the state of the Markov process at time t

Pij(n,t)=Pr{Nt=n,Jt=j|N0=0,J0=i}

Pij(n,t) is the (i,j) element of matrix P(n,t), the matrices satisfy the forward Chapman-Kolmogorov equations:

{P′(0,t)=P(0,t)(Q−Λ)P′(n,t)=P(n,t)(Q−Λ)+P(n−1,t)Λ,n≥1,t≥0

the matrix generating function P∗(z,t)=∑∞n=0P(n,t)zn=e(Q−(1−z)Λ)t then satisfies

ddtP∗(z,t)=P∗(z,t)(Q−Λ)+zP∗(z,t)Λ,P∗(z,0)=I

so that

P∗(z,t)=e(Q−(1−z)Λ)t,|z|≤1

And, we derive that the generating function of the number of arrivals is g(z,t)=π{e(Q−(1−z)Λ)t}e
where π is the steady-state probability vector of Markov chain and e=(1,1,…,1)T
Then for the time-stationary version of the MMPP E[Nt]=g′(1,t)=π{e(Q−(1−z)Λ)tΛt}e|z=1=πλt

1.2 The service process — general distribution

The service time distribution is notated as H˜(x) with finite mean h, second and third moments h(2) and h(3) and LST (Laplac-Stieltjies Transform) H(s)

H(s)=E[e−sx]=∫∞0e−sx dH˜(x)

h(m)=E[xm]=(−1)mH(m)(s) ∣∣ s=0

A.The negative exponential distribution

The probability density function is

h(x)={μe−μx,0,x≥0x<0

The cumulative distribution function is H˜(x)=1−e−μx. The LST H(s) is given by

H(s)=E[e−sx]=∫∞0e−sx dH˜(x)=μs+μh=E(x)=1μh(2)=E(x2)=2μ2h(3)=E(x3)=6μ3

The steady-state vector of G satisfies

G=∫∞0e(Q−Λ+ΛG)xdH˜(x)gG=g,ge=1

B.The geometric distribution

The probability density function is

h(x)=p(1−p)x−1,x=1,2,3,…

The cumulative distribution function is

H˜(x)=∑x=1∞h(x)=1−(1−p)x

The LST H(s) is given by

H(s)=E[e−sx]=∫∞0e−sx dH˜(x)=1s−ln(1−p)h=E(x)=1p

1.3 Queue model analyze

The arrival process is described as 1.1 and the service process is described as 1.2

Let {τn:n≥0} denote the successive epochs of departure (with τ0=0), and define Xn and Jn to be the number of customers in the system and the state of MMPP at time τ+n. The sequence {(Xn,Jn,τn+1−τn): n≥0} forms a semi-Markov sequence on the state space {0,1,…}×{1,…,m}. The semi-Markov process is positive recurrent when traffic intensity ρ=hλtot<1. The transition probability matrix is

Q˜(x)=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢B˜0(x)A˜0(x)00⋮B˜1(x)A˜1(x)A˜0(x)0⋮B˜2(x)A˜2(x)A˜1(x)A˜0(x)⋮⋯⋯⋯⋯⋱⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥

For n≥0 , A˜n(x) and B˜n(x) are the m×m matrices of mass function defined by:

[A˜n(x)]ij=Pr{Given a departure at time 0, which left at least one customer in the system and the arrival process is at state i, the next departure occurs no later than time x with the arrival process in state j,and during that service time there were n arrivals}

[B˜n(x)]ij=Pr{Given a departure at time 0, which left the system empty and the arrival process in state i,the next departure occurs no later than x with arrival process in state j,leaving n customers at system}

Review P(n,t) the counting function , it is clear that

A˜n(x)=∫x0P(n,t) dH˜(t), n≥0,x≥0

define the LST and z-transform:

An(s)=∫∞0e−sx dA˜n(x),Bs(s)=∫∞0e−sxdB˜n(x)A(z,s)=∑n=0∞An(s)zn,B(z,s)=∑n=0∞Bn(s)znAn=An(0)=A˜n(∞),Bn=Bn(0)=B˜n(∞)A=A(1,0),B=B(1,0)

A(z,s)=∫∞0e−sxe[(Q−Λ)+zΛ]xdH˜(x)A=∫∞0eQtdH˜(t)

Aij is the probability that a service ends with the MMPP in state j given that the service began in state i. We note that the matrix A is stochastic, and the stationary vector π also satisfies πA=π, πe=1
Define the vector β, and the jth element is βj, is the conditional number of arrivals during a service which starts with the arrival process is at state j

β=∑k=0∞kAk=ddzA(z,0)|z=1e=ρe+(Q+eπ)−1(A−I)λ

And the matrices B˜n(x) are related to the matrices A˜n(x) by

B˜n(x)=∫x0dU˜(t)A˜n(x−t)=U˜(x)⊛A˜n(x)

where

U˜(x)=∫x0e(Q−A)tΛdt

So that

Bn=(Λ−Q)−1ΛAn

1.3.1 The queue length distribution at departure instants

The embedded Markov chain at departures which has transition probability matrix Q˜(∞), write the stationary vector of Q˜(∞) as x=(x0,x1,⋯). We obtain the system of equations

xQ˜(∞)=xxi=x0Bi+∑v=1ixvAi+1−v,i≥0

where xi=(xi,1,xi,2,⋯) is vector and

xij=Pr{a departure leaves the system behind with i customers and the MMPP in state j}

the quantities xi can be determined once x0 is known using the method described in the section below. The vector x0 can be obtained by studying the downward transition of Q˜(∞). In order to reach level 0 from level i, each level in between must be visited, which is knowns as the left skip-free property. Moreover, the chance mechanism governing the first passage from levle i+1 to level i is the same for all levels with i≥0, because of the spatial homogeneity of the Markovian chain. Therefore, the first passage time distributions from level i+1 to level i, i≥0, play a crucial role in the study of the return time distribution to level 0.

Define Gij as the probability that a busy period starting with the MMPP in state i and ends in state j (equivalently, the probability that the first passage from (k+1,i) to (k,j) ). The matrix G is the root of

G=∫∞0e(Q−Λ+ΛG)xdH˜(x)

The steady-state vector of G satisfies

gG=g,ge=1

And x0 is explicitly given by:

x0=1−ρλtot⋅g(Λ−Q)

先不考虑

Conceptually, the recursion of xi can be used to determine the quantities xi.
Set

X(z)=∑0∞xizi

The moments of the queue length at the departures can be obtained by differentiating X(x). It can be shown that

X(z)[zI−A(z)]=−x0(Q−Λ)−1D(z)A(z)

where D(z)=(Q−Λ)+zΛ, from which it can be shown that

X′e=12(1−ρ)⋅{XA(2)e+U(2)e+2{−U(1)−X[I−A(1)]}(I−A+eπ)−1β}

and

X′′e=13(1−ρ)⋅{3X(1)A(2)e+XA(3)e+U(3)e+3{U(2)+XA(2)−2X(1)[I−A(1)]}(I−A+eπ−1β}

where U(z)=−x0(Q−Λ)−1D(z)A(z) and

X(i)=X(i)(1), U(i)=U(i)(1), A(i)=A(i)(1)

and we can explicitly write

U(z)=−x0(Q−Λ)−1D(z)A(z),U′(z)=−x0(Q−Λ)−1[D(z)A′(z)+ΛA(z)],U′′(z)=−x0(Q−Λ)−1[D(z)A′′(z)+2ΛA′(z)],U(3)(z)=−x0(Q−Λ)−1[D(z)A(3)+3ΛA′′(z)]

1.3.2 The queue length distribution at an arbitrary time

In this section we derive the formulas for the stationary queue length distribution at an arbitrary time. We define the following stationary probabilities:

yi,j=Pr{at an arbitrary time there are i customers in the system and the MMPP is in state j}

and

yi=(yi,1,yi,2,…,yi,m)

and it can be shown that

y0=(1−ρ)g

and

yi=(yi−1Λ−λtot(xi−1−xi))(Λ−Q)−1

the unconditional system size distribution at an arbitary time is given by

pi=yie

Finally, it can be shown that the unconditional system size distribution at customer arrival instants, zi, which is identical to the queue length distribution at customer departure instant is

zi=xie=1λtot⋅yiλ

Set

Y(z)=∑i=0∞yizi

The moments of the system size at an arbitrary time are given by

Y(1)e=X(1)e+[1λtotπΛ−X](eπ+Q)−1Λe

and

Y(2)e=X(2)e−2[X(1)−1λtotY(1)Λ](eπ+Q)−1Λe

1.3.3 The waiting time distribution

In this section, we calculate the vartual waiting time. Furthermore we introduce the following notation:

W˜(x)={W˜1(x),W˜2(x),…,W˜m(x)},where W˜j(x) is the joint probability that atan arbitrary timeand the system is in state j and a virtual customer whoarrives at that time the waiting time at most x before starting service.

Then the LST of the virtual waiting time distribution is given by:

Wv(s)=∫∞0e−sxdW˜(x),wv(s)=Wv(s)e

The notation H˜(u) is service time distribution, and joint distribution of the virtual waiting time and the state of the MMPP satisfies the Volterra integral equation.

W˜(x)=y0−∫x0W˜(u)duQ+∫x0W˜(x−u)[1−H˜(u)]duΛ

we derive that the joint LST transform of the virtual waiting time and the MMPP’s state is shown as follow:

Wv(s)={sy0[sI+Q−Λ(1−H(s))]−1,π,for s>0,for s=0

The transform of the virtual waiting time Wv(s) satisfies

wv(s)=wv(x)e=sy0[sI+Q−Λ(1−H(s))]−1e

先不考虑

and the transform of the waiting time at customer arrival instants Wa(s) can either be calculated from the general relationship

Wa(s)=shρ(1−H(s))⋅(wv(s)+ρ−1)=1λ¯¯⋅Wv(s)λ

wv=12(1−ρ)[2ρ+λ¯¯h(2)−2h((1−ρ)g+hπΛ)(Q+eπ)−1λ]

w(2)v=13(1−ρ)[3h(2W′(0)(hΛ−I)−h(2)πΛ)(Q+eπ)−1−3h(2)W′(0)λ+λ¯¯h(3)]

with

W′(0)=(hπΛ+(1−ρ)g)(Q+eπ)−1−π(1+wv)

W′′(0)=(2W′(0)(hΛ−I)−h(2)πΛ)(Q+eπ)−1+w(2)vπ

wa=1ρ(wv−12λ¯¯h(2))

w(2)a=1ρ(w(2)v−λ¯¯h(3)3−λ¯¯wah(2))

1.3.4 Numerical Solution

Step.1 Compute the matrix G

solve the equation：

G=∫∞0e(Q−Λ+ΛG)xdH˜(x)

Using Newtow-Raphson method to get the numerical result

Initial Step. Define

G0=0,H0,k=I,k=0,1,2,…

Θ=maxi((Λ−Q)ii),γn=∫∞0e−Θx(Θx)nn!dH˜(x), n=0,1,…,n∗

where n∗ is chosen such that ∑n∗k=1γk>1−ϵ1, ϵ1≪1.

Recursion. For k=0,1,2,…, compute

Hn+1,k=[I+1Θ(Q−Λ+ΛGk)]Hn,k,n=0,1,2,…,n∗Gk+1=∑n=0n∗γnHn,k

Stop criterion

||Gk−1−Gk||<ϵ2≪1.

Set

G=Gk+1

Step 2. Compute the steady state vector g which satisfies

gG=g,ge=1

Step 3. Compute:

x0=1−ρλtotg(Λ−Q)

Step 4. Compute the system size distribution at departures and the moments of the queue length distribution at departures (See 1.3.1)
Step 5. Compute

y0=(1−ρ)g

Step 6. Compute the queue length distributiuon at an arbitrary time using the queue length distributions at departures

yi=(yi−1Λ−λtot(xi−1−xi))(Λ−Q)−1

Step 7. Compute waiting time distributions transform and/or moments (See 1.3.3)

2. The arrival process - Markovian TCP source model

2.1 Defs

  1. Delayed ACK : acknowledge b pacekt once
  2. Timer : TS, Reset after receive an ACK，until a newer ACK is received（@sender）
  3. Time-out TO : no more data is sent until the expect byte is ACKed
  4. Dup-ACK TD :
  5. Current window (in segment) : Wc
  6. Slow start threshold(SSTH): Wss
  7. Max allowed window size Wmax

2.2 The Model

2.2.1 The State Space

The evolution of the CWND of TCP is described by a homogeneous discrete time Markov chain(DTMC)：Xn=(Wcn,Wssn), where Wcn is the CNWD in the nth round, and Wssn is the SSTH. When time out occurs, Wcn=0, the maximum CNWD is Wmax.

The state space is:

  1. Xn=(i,j),i∈{1,2,…,Wmax} and j∈{2,…,⌊Wmax/2⌋}，not in the TO state.
  2. Xn=(0,j),j∈{2,…,⌊Wmax/2⌋} , in the TO state

As long as Wcn>1, the DTMC transit from a state to another state every round
In order to make the mean duration(in seconds) of a time-out period E[Tto] equal to RTT times the mean number of successive visits to state (0,j), the following transitions are defined:

  • (0,j)→(1,j) with probability p0 at the end of a time-out period
  • (0,j)→(0,j) with probability otherwise.
  • p0=RTT/E[Tto]

The state space of this DTMC is the subset of E′={0,…,Wmax}×{2,…,⌊Wmax⌋}, because some states will never be reached. The state space is:

E=E0⋃A⋃B
E0={(0,j) | 2≤j≤⌊Wmax/2⌋}
B={(i,j) | 2≤j≤i≤Wmax and j≤⌊Wmax/2⌋}
A={(i,j) | 1≤i<j≤⌊Wmax/2⌋ and ∃n≥0 such that i=f[n](1)} where f(w)=w+⌈w/b⌉, f[0](w)=w, f[n]=f[n−1]∘f, for n≥1

The arrival rate of the TCP source depends on the current state. The instant send rate of the TCP source is Wcnλ0, where λ0 is the send rate when Wcn=1.

2.2.2 Notations in the model

  • Tto : duration of to period, Tss: slow start phase, Tca congestion avoidance phase
  • dto,dss and dca:segments sent during the Tto,Tss,Tca
  • TbackE0:the time between time out recovery and the next TO loss
  • dbackE0:the segments sent during TbackE0
  • Nloss:the mean number of loss detection per cycle
  • ρ : throughput, send rate, distinguished with goodput

  • ρ=E[dbackE0]+E[dto]E[TbackE0]+E[Tto]

2.2.3 State transition

2.2.3.1 Slow start

condition： 1≤i<j≤⌊Wmax/2⌋

  1. P(i,j)(⌈γi⌉,j)=(1−p)i -> no loss
  2. P(i,j)(0,max(⌊i/2⌋,2))=[1−(1−p)i]qi -> time out
  3. P(i,j)(max(⌊i/2⌋,1),max(⌊i/2⌋,2))=[1−(1−p)i](1−qi) -> Dup ack
2.2.3.2 Congestion avoidance

condition: 1≤j≤i<Wmax

CWND is increased by 1/b every round

  1. P(i,j)(i,j)=（1−p)i(1−1/b) -> no loss
  2. P(i,j)(i+1,j)=(1−p)i(1/b) -> no loss
  3. P(i,j)(0,max(⌊i/2⌋,2))=[1−(1−p)i]qi -> time out
  4. P(i,j)(max(⌊i/2⌋,1),max(⌊i/2⌋,2))=[1−(1−p)i](1−qi) -> Dup ack
2.2.3.3 max window

condition i=Wmax

  1. P(Wmax,j)(Wmax,j)=（1−p)Wmax -> No loss
  2. P(Wmax,j)(0,max(⌊Wmax/2⌋,2))=[1−(1−p)Wmax]qWmax -> TO
  3. P(Wmax,j)(max(⌊Wmax/2⌋,1),max(⌊Wmax/2⌋,2))=[1−(1−p)Wmax](1−qWmax) -> Dup
2.2.3.4 Time out

for each j

  1. P(0,j)(0,j)=1−(RTT/E[Tto]) -> no acknowledge yet
  2. P(0,j)(1,j)=RTT/E[Tto] -> ack received
2.2.3.5 Compute qi

We assume that losses only occur in the direction from the sender to the receiver (no loss of ACKs) and that any segment has a fixed probability p to get lost. More precisely, the random variable defined by the number of consecutive segments that are transmitted before loss has a geometric distribution with parameter 1−p
The probability qi that a loss is due to TO when Wc=i is given by:

qi=1if i≤2b+1

and

qi=[1−(1−p)2b+1][1+(1−p)2b+1−(1−p)i]1−(1−p)i if i≤2b+1

proof

  • if i≤2b+1 then k≤2b, dup is no possible to happen (no enough segment trigger dup ack) thus the the loss must due to TO

  • if i≥2b+1 then:

    • if k≤2b, only TO is possible
    • if k≥2b+1, only less than 2b+1 segments are received in the next residual round arriving at the receiver （the first 2B+1 packets in the residual round are not received all）,i.e. the lth segment from the residual round get lost 1≤l≤2b+1

    denote Lk+1 as the event corresponding to the loss of the (k+1)th segment is loss, then

    qi=p(TO|Wc=i and loss)=∑k=0i−1qi,kP(Lk+1|Wc=i and loss)

    where

    qi,k=P(TO|Wc=i and Lk+1)={1,1−(1−p)2b+1,k≤2bk≥2b+1

    and

    P(Lk+1|Wc=i & Lk+1)=((1−p)kp）/(1−(1−p)i)

2.2.4 The transition probability matrix

In the section 1, the infinitesimal generator of the Markovian chain is notated as Q. And we now have the state transition probability matrix P, indeed the relationship between P and Q is simply:

Q=P−I

The state of the DTMC is represented by a tuple Xn=(Wcn,Wthn), we arrange the states in a single line as the Wcn order. For example, the one-line state is X′1,X′2,X′3,…,X′n=(0,2),(0,3),(0,4),…,(Wmax,⌊Wmax/2⌋)
